abstract.p: The performance of dye-sensitized solar cells can be improved by building the photoanode from spindle-shaped nanoparticles.

body.p: Plants are naturally good at capturing energy from the sun thanks to the chlorophyll dye in their leaves. Inspired by this, researchers have developed dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs), which present a low-cost alternative to existing semiconductor photovoltaics.

In a typical DSSC, a photoanode made from titanium dioxide (titanate) nanoparticles is coated with light-absorbing dye. Shihe Yang and co-workers at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology in China1 have now improved the efficiency of DSSCs through the use of high-quality spindle-shaped nanoparticles.
Fig. 1: Scanning electron microscopy images of a photanode made from layers of large (upper) and small (lower) titanate nanospindles. Insets are approximately 2 μm across.© 2010 Wiley-VCH

It was previously known that photoanodes made from small particles have a large overall surface area that allows them to hold large numbers of light-absorbing dye molecules. However, small-particle structures with a limited thickness can be partially transparent, meaning that larger particles are required in order to intercept and scatter light effectively. It has proved difficult to reconcile size, surface area and charge collection for the best overall energy transfer to the cell. Yang and his colleagues addressed the issue by using nanospindles with tunable diameter and length.

“Our synthesis method is a ‘divide and conquer’ approach,” says Yang, referring to a method in which nanospindles are obtained by cutting up long titanate nanotubes. “By choosing different reaction media, we were able to synthesize nanospindles of several sizes with high crystalline quality.”

These nanospindles served as the basis for a new type of double-layer photoanode (see figure). One of the layers is made from small nanospindles that absorb light, while the other is made from larger nanospindles that tend to pack together in bundles and scatter light. The high quality of the crystals also contributes to improving overall charge collection.

A DSSC constructed using the new photoanode displayed a light-to-electricity conversion efficiency of more than 8.3%, outperforming both single-layer nanospindle-based and nanoparticle-based cells. Yang is hopeful that even more efficient cells could be created in the future by tuning the combination of layers.

“At present, our work is still limited to laboratory demonstrations. However, large-scale production is quite possible because the synthesis is simple and scalable,” he says. “Our technique may eventually lead to large-scale applications such as powering buildings, but more research is needed.”

mixed-citation.article-title: Double-layered photoanodes from variable-size anatase TiO2 nanospindles: A candidate for high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells.
